intro: Adenoropium hernandiifolium, commonly known as the Mexican mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees in Mexico and Central America. It has small, leathery leaves that are opposite and elliptic in shape, often with a waxy coating. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences. Its berries are typically red or yellow and contain sticky seeds that adhere to birds for dispersal. Botanically, it belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its parasitic nature and unique reproductive strategies.
